turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I've often thought about going back.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: You have?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Oh, yes. I used to have a lot of fun there when I was a little girl. I used to love to go fishing with my father. That's funny. He was a lot like you, my father was. Talked like you, too. Sometimes he'd let me hold the line while he smoked - and we'd just sit there for hours. And after awhile, for no reason, I'd go over and kiss him and sit in his lap. He never said very much but once I remember him saying: "No matter what happens, honey, don't complain."

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: He sounds like a person worth while knowing.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: He played in the town band, too.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: He did? I play the tuba

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Yeah, I know.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What did he play?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: The drums. He taught me to play some.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: He did?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Yes. I can do "Swanee River." Would you like to hear me?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Sure!

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Oh, I suppose you could do better.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Sure. I can sing "Humoresque."

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: "Humoresque"? I'll bet you don't even know how it goes.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Sure. Look! You sing it over again, and I'll do "Humoresque" with you.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: It had better be good.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Couldn't sleep. Kinda wanted to talk to you. Do you mind?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: No - not at all. I couldn't sleep either.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I wanted to thank you again for going out with me.  Huh? Well, I don't know what I'd do without you. You've made up for all the fakes that I've met.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Well, that's very nice. Thank you.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: You know what I've been doing since I got home? Been working on a poem.  It's about you.  Sometimes it's kinda hard for me to say things - so I write 'em.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I'd like to read it some time.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I didn't think you could come with the party and everything.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, I wouldn't let them stop me from seeing you. So I threw them out!

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: You threw them out!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Yes, if it isn't too late.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I'll get my hat.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Ready?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Gosh, she looks better every time I see her.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: The reason why I wanted to take a walk, Mary, is 'cause I wanted to talk to you.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Let's just walk, okay?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Mary, I'm going home.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Are you? When?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: In a day or so, I think.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I don't blame you.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Do you mind if I talk to you, Mary? You don't have to pay any attention to me.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: No, I don't mind.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: All my life, I've wanted somebody to talk to. Back in Mandrake Falls, I always used to talk to a girl.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: A girl?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, an imaginary one. I used to hike a lot through the woods and I'd always take this girl with me so I could talk to her. I'd show her my pet trees and things. Sounds kind of silly but we had a lot of fun doing it.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, here we are again.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Yes, here we are again.  Good night.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Mary - I - excuse me

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Would you like to read it? It's to you.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Yes, of course.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Hello, Mary?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Oh, hello darling.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: What's the matter, hon?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: What's up, Babe? Something's eating you.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: No. It's nothing.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: My unfailing instinct tells me something's gone wrong with the stew.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: You haven't gotten very far, have you? That's where you were an hour ago. Come on, let's knock off and go down to Joe's. The gang's waiting for us.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I can't write it, Mabel! I don't know what's the matter with me.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Mabel, that guy's either the dumbest, the stupidest, the most imbecilic idiot in the world - or he's the grandest thing alive. I can't make him out.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I'm crucifying him.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: People have been crucified before.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Why? Why do we have to do it?

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: You started out to be a successful newspaper woman, didn't you?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Yeah, then what?

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Search me. Ask the Gypsies.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Here's a guy that's wholesome and fresh. To us he looks like a freak. You know what he told me tonight? He said when he gets married he wants to carry his bride over the threshold in his arms.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: The guy's balmy.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Is he? Yeah, I thought so, too. I tried to laugh, but I couldn't. It stuck in my throat.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Aw, cut it out, will you? You'll get me thinking about Charlie again.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: He's got goodness, Mabel. Do you know what that is?

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: No - of course you don't. We've forgotten. We're too busy being smart-alecks.  Too busy in a crazy competition for nothing.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: You're a fool, Babe.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I just couldn't stand seeing him again.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Running away is no solution.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: What'll I tell him if he calls up?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Tell him I had to leave suddenly. I got a job in China - some place.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: You're acting like a school girl.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: What else can I do? Keeping this up is no good. He's bound to find out sometime.  At least I can save him that .

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Just a minute. No, you don't.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: We're not going out tonight.

turns.speaker: MABEL
turns.text: Why there she is!  Of course she's home.  Stupid of me . . .

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Look, I can do it!

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: What's gotten into you, Babe? I remember the time when you'd blast this town wide open before you'd let Cobb get away with a thing like this.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Oh, he's not getting away with anything.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Listen, Babe - get me some stuff on this guy, and you can have

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Can I have a month's vacation?

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: With pay!

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: With pay!

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Leave four columns open on the front page tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Now you're talking, Babe. I'll keep the whole front page open. What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Have lunch.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Cinderella Man! That's sensational, Babe! Sensational!

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: It took some high-powered acting, believe me.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Did it?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I was the world's sweetest ingenue.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Is he really that big a sap?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: He's the original. There are no carbon copies of that one.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Cinderella Man! Babe, you stuck a tag on that hick that'll stick to him the rest of his life. Can you imagine Cobb's face when he reads this?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: If we could sell tickets, we'd make a fortune.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: How'd you get the picture?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Had the boys follow us.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Marvelous!  "At two o'clock this morning, Mr. Deeds tied up traffic while he fed a bagful of doughnuts to a horse. When asked why he was doing it, he replied: 'I just wanted to see how many doughnuts this horse would eat before he'd ask for a cup of coffee.'"  Beautiful! What happened after that?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I don't know. I had to duck to get the story out. He was so far along he never even missed me.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: When're you going to see him again?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Tonight, maybe.  I'll phone him at noon.  Oh, my lunch hour. I'm a stenographer, you know. Mary Dawson.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: You're a genius, Babe - a genius!

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I even moved into Mabel Dawson's apartment - in case old snoopy Cobb might start looking around.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Good! Good!  Stay there. Don't show your face down here. I'll tell everybody you're on your vacation. They'll never know where the stories are coming from. Stick close to him, Babe - you can get an exclusive story out of him every day for a month. We'll have the other papers crazy.  Babe, I could kiss you!

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Oh, no. No. Our deal was for a month's vacation - with pay.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: With pay!  She is out the door.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: You'll get it, Babe. You'll get it.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: What's bothering you, huh?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Last night he proposed to me.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Proposed to you! You mean he asked you to marry him?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Why, Babe - that's terrific!  "Cinderella Man Woos Mystery Girl! Who is the Mysterious Girl That"

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Print one line of that, and I'll blow your place up!

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Sorry, Babe. Sorry. It would have made a swell story. I just got carried away. That's too bad. So he proposed to you, huh?  What a twist! You set out to nail him - and he

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Yeah. Funny twist, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Say, you haven't gone and fallen for that mug, have you?

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: What're you going to do?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I'm going to tell him the truth.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Tell him you're Babe Bennett? Tell him you've been making a stooge out of him?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: I'm having lunch with him today. He expects an answer. It's going to be pretty.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: You're crazy! You can't do that!

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: He'll probably kick me right down the stairs. I only hope he does.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: I'll put you on another job. You need never see him again, eh?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: That's the rub.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Oh, as bad as that, huh?

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Telling him is the long shot - I'm going to take it.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: This is for you , Mac. The names of all the headwaiters in town. You can always buy a bit of choice scandal from them at reasonable prices.

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: Aw, listen Babe, I can't let you quit now. You're not going through with this thing, are you?

turns.speaker: MAC
turns.text: It's for you. In a couple weeks you'll get the itch so bad, you'll be working for nothing.

turns.speaker: BABE
turns.text: Hello . . .

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I suppose it's going to be the same old thing.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I tell you that dame's nuts.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Come on, come on!

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Hurry up!

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: It don't look as though we're gonna get any pictures tonight.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Babe ought to get him drunk again.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I wonder if they'd want to make it a quartet.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Shhh!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah. Mac threw Cobb out again.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Boy, was he burning.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Just one little drink - and then we're ready to shoot.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Ow! My foot's asleep!

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Come on - let's go!

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: We've got nothing to worry about. He's as naive as a child.

turns.speaker: BUDINGTON
turns.text: John

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Close that door.  Will you get Mrs. Cedar on the phone, please?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I know, Budington. We can't afford to have the books investigated right now. You must have said that a thousand times already.

turns.speaker: BUDINGTON
turns.text: But what if they fall into somebody else's hands, why - uh

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Well, it hasn't happened yet - has it?

turns.speaker: BUDINGTON
turns.text: But a half million dollars! My goodness, where are we going to get

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Will you stop worrying! It was I who got old man Semple to turn everything over to us, wasn't it? And who got the Power of Attorney from him ! All right, and I'll get it again!  I'll take it easy. Those books'll never leave this office.

turns.speaker: BUDINGTON
turns.text: don't want to be critical, John, but here it is

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Yes, I know. A week's gone by and we haven't got the Power of Attorney yet!

turns.speaker: BUDINGTON
turns.text: Yes, but you said

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I don't care what I said. I can't strangle him, can I!

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: The gentlemen from the opera are still waiting in the board room, sir. They're getting a trifle impatient, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: They are? I forgot all about them.  What do you think they want?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Will you show Mr. Hallor to the front door?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Cobb's right. I mustn't talk to anybody.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Miss Dawson on the phone, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Who? Miss Dawson?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Fine. I'll talk to her. Give me the phone, quick. She's the only one I'm going to talk to from now on.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: You try it.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Me, sir?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: How's it going? Okay?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Yes, quite all right. Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Gold, eh?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Fourteen carat?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Is that the best you've got?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Oh, yes sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Those flowers are too high. Won't be able to see her.  Get a smaller bowl, will you?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: A smaller bowl of flowers.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Stuff, sir?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: That goo. That stuff that tastes like soap.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Oh, yes, sir. Here it is, sir. The pate de fois gras, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Yeah, that's fine. Have a lot of it because she likes it.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Sit over there, will you?

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: Me sir?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: How is this, sir?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Perfect! Perfect!

turns.speaker: BUTLER
turns.text: I wish you luck, sir.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Thank you. Now don't touch a thing. Leave everything as it is.

turns.speaker: BUTLERS
turns.text: You can't come up here!

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: Let me go! I wanna see him!

turns.speaker: BUTLERS
turns.text: He's not home, I tell you!

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: I wanna see that guy!

turns.speaker: BUTLERS
turns.text: We'll send for the police!

turns.speaker: FARMER
turns.text: Let me go!

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Thank heaven.

turns.speaker: FIRST BROTHER
turns.text: Better wire him right away, John.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I'll do no such thing. I'm going there myself. You're going with me too, Anderson - and you too, Cobb.

turns.speaker: FIRST BROTHER
turns.text: Come on, John. What happened?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: The smartest thing I ever did was to make that trip.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Relatives of old man Semple.

turns.speaker: FIRST BROTHER
turns.text: They keep insisting they should have some nuisance value.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Nuisance value?

turns.speaker: FIRST BROTHER
turns.text: They say if it hadn't been for Deeds, they'd have gotten all the money.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Nuisance value.  Maybe they have! Maybe they have! Maybe they have!  Mr. and Mrs. Semple, please. How do you do?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Miss Bennett please!

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: This is outrageous!

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: The Falkner sisters are rather timid, Your Honor, and wish to be together. If the court pleases, I will only have one of them testify.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Yes! Yes! Let's get on with it.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Must we have the echo?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Suppose you just answer, Miss Jane. Now, will you tell the Court what everybody at home thinks of Longfellow Deeds?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: He's what?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: What was that you said he was?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Your Honor, I object.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Proceed.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: It's a lie!

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Mr. Cedar!

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Mr. Deeds is drawing on his warped imagination!

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: You will please permit Mr. Deeds to finish.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: But your honor

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Mr. Cedar!

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Newspaperman?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Wants to know who the heir is.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Hang up.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Sorry, Mac, I can't. Yeah, Mac. Sure, but I ain't the attorney

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Hang up.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Mr. Cedar is, and I haven't seen him in two days.  Listen, Cedar, we've got to do something about the newspapers.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I'm not interested in the newspapers.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: But it's a great story. Somewhere in this country a guy is walking into twenty million bucks.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Yes, I know. My first concern is to locate the lucky man. When I do, it's your job to keep the newspapers away from him.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: It's okay with me as long as my weekly stipend keeps coming in.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: That's pretty.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Are you sure this is the town he lives in?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I guess we'd better try somebody else.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: No, we won't! The next time that jumping jack comes out, I'll straddle him while you ask him your questions.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Yeah. A glorified doormat.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Yes. You see, rich people need someone to keep the crowds away. The world's full of pests. Then there's the newspapers to handle. One must know when to seek publicity - and when to avoid it.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I can understand that.  We'll take a walk around town, meet you at the train at four o'clock.  Congratulations, Mr. Deeds. You're one of the richest men in the country. We'll see you later.  Goodbye and thank you.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: See you later, kid.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: I can't find him.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: You can't?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: I looked everywhere. I even went to his house. It's locked up.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Look!

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: That tuba player!

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Well, your uncle was Chairman of the Board of Directors. They probably expect you to carry on.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: I'll tell those mugs to keep their shirts on, that you'll be right down.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Make three reservations on the first train out to Mandrake Falls, Vermont.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Mandrake Falls.  M-A-N

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Charlie, we're off! Papers all set?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: All set.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Okay, then. Go to it.  And, Charlie

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Find out who wrote those newspaper articles and subpoena them right away.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Mr. Longfellow Deeds?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: How do you do.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: How do you do.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I'm John Cedar - of the New York firm of Cedar, Cedar, Cedar and Budington.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I'd like to ask you a few questions.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Mr. Deeds, are you the son of Dr. Joseph and Mary Deeds?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Are your parents living?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Why, no.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Mr. Deeds, does the name of Martin W. Semple mean anything to you?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Not much. He's an uncle of mine, I think. I never saw him, but my mother's name was Semple, you know.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Well, he passed on. He was killed in a motor accident in Italy.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: He was? Gee, that's too bad. If there's anything I can do to

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Perhaps you didn't hear what I said, Mr. Deeds! The whole Semple fortune goes to you! $20,000,000!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, yes, I heard you all right. $20,000,000. That's quite a lot, isn't it?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Mr. Cobb here is an ex-newspaperman associated with your uncle for many years - as a sort of buffer.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Buffer?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Are you a married man, Mr. Deeds?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Who - me? No.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Saving a lady in distress, eh? Well, I suppose we all have dreams like that when we are young.  Incidentally, we'd better get started. You'll have to pack.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: You're going to New York with us.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Will you have a cigar?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: No, thank you.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I wouldn't worry if I were you. Of course, a large fortune like this entails a great responsibility - but you'll have a good deal of help. So don't worry. Leave everything to me.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, I wasn't worried about that.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: No?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I was wondering where they're going to get another tuba player for the band.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: It's merely a suggestion. I don't wish to press the point, Mr. Deeds, but if you'll give me your Power of Attorney we'll take care of everything. It'll save you a lot of petty annoyances. Every shark in town will be trying to sell you something.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, yes, there've been a lot of them around here already. Strangest kind of people. Salesmen - politicians - moochers - all want something. I haven't had a minute to myself. Haven't seen Grant's Tomb yet.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Well, you see, your uncle didn't bother with that sort of thing. He left everything to us. He traveled most of the time, and enjoyed himself. You should do the same thing, Mr. Deeds.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Besides wanting to be my lawyer, you also want to handle my investments too?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Yes. That is to say

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, outside of your regular fee, how much extra will it cost?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Oh - nothing. No extra charge.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: That involves a lot of extra work, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Yes, but that's an added service a firm like Cedar, Cedar, Cedar and Budington usually donates.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Budington. Funny, I can't think of a rhyme for Budington yet.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I think you ought to give this matter some thought, Mr. Deeds.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I mean, about the Power of Attorney.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, yes. Yes, I will.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Why not? Who is he?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: A lawyer representing some woman with a claim against the estate.  Tell him to see me at my office.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, if he has a claim, we'd better see him.  Send him in.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: He's capable of causing you a lot of trouble, Mr. Deeds.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: How can he make any trouble for me? I haven't done anything.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: I can't hold out any longer either, Mr. Deeds.  Being an attorney for you will be a very simple affair.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: You're not my attorney yet, Mr. Cedar. Not till I find out what's on your mind. Suppose you get the books straightened out quick so I can have a look at them.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Yes, of course, if you wish. But you must be prepared. This sort of thing will be daily routine.  If it becomes annoying, you let me know. Goodbye, Mr. Deeds. Goodbye, sir.

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: Oh, will you come in please, gentlemen?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Is Mr. Deeds in?

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: No - he's over to the park arranging for the bazaar, so's to raise money for the fire engine.  Mal, you shoulda knowed he was in the park.

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: Come in, please. Come in. Can I get you a cup of tea?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: No, thanks.

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: Sit down. Sure I couldn't get you a glass of lemonade or something?

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: That's very kind of you. Are you related to him?

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: No, I'm his housekeeper.

turns.speaker: CEDAR
turns.text: Well, we'd like to find out something about him. What does he do for a living?

turns.speaker: MRS. MEREDITH
turns.text: He and Jim Mason own the Tallow Works. But that's not where he makes his money. He makes most of it from his poetry.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Oh, it'll do in a pinch.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Yes, indeed. I wonder why he left me all that money? I don't need it.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Cedar, Cedar, Cedar and Budington. Funny, I can't think of a rhyme for Budington.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Why should you?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Well, whenever I run across a funny name, I always like to poke around for a rhyme. Don't you?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Nah.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I've got one for Cobb

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: "There once was a man named Cobb, Who kept Semple away from the mob. Came the turn of the tide And Semple - he died - And now poor Cobb's out of a job!"

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Sounds like a two weeks' notice to me.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: I've gotten the 'sackaroo' in many ways - but never in rhyme.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, I don't mean that. I'm sure I'm going to need your help.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Oh, that's different if it's just poetry.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: This afternoon - at four o'clock.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I don't think we've got any suitcases.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Have a drink?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: No, thanks.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Thanks  Oh, did you send that telegram to Jim Mason?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Jim Mason?  Oh, yeah. Yeah. No, I didn't send it. I've got it written out, though. Here it is.  "Arthur's been with the Tallow Works too long. STOP. Don't think we should fire him. Longfellow."

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Fine. Send it right away. I don't want him to fire Arthur.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Oh, sure. Sure. We don't want to fire Arthur.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: He was the last baby my father delivered, Arthur was.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: You'd better get right down there. That opera mob is about to break into the Mad Song from "Lucia."[2]

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, I don't want to keep them waiting any longer. They're important people.  I wish you'd go along with me, Cobb. They're all strangers to me.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Gee, I'm busy. Did the opera people always come here for their meetings?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: That's funny. Why is that?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Why do mice go where there's cheese?[3]

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: I can't hold out on you any longer. Lamb bites wolf.  Beautiful.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Only common sense.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Well, how about tonight? What would you like in the way of entertainment?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Entertainment?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Your uncle had a weakness for dark ones, tall and stately. How would you like yours? Dark or fair, tall or short, fat or thin, tough or tender?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What're you talking about?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Women! Ever heard of 'em?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Name your poison and I'll supply it.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Some other time, Cobb. Some other time.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Okay, you're the boss.  When your blood begins to boil, yell out. I'll be seeing you!

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Did you see all this stuff in the papers?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Arthur wants to quit!

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Arthur! Who's Arthur?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: He's the shipping clerk at the Tallow Works. Wants a $2 raise - or he'll quit.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: What do I care about Arthur! Did you see this stuff in the paper? How'd it get in there? What'd you do last night? Who were you talking to?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: And what'd you do to those bodyguards? They quit this morning. Said you locked them up.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Oh, they insisted on following me.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: What do you think bodyguards are for?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: What do they mean by this - "Cinderella Man!"

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Are those stories true?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I don't remember. "Cinderella Man!" What do they mean by that?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: They'd call you anything if you gave them half a chance. They've got you down as a sap.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: I think I'll go down and punch this editor on the nose.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: No, you don't! Get this clear: Socking people is no solution for anything.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Sometimes it's the only solution.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Not editors. Take my word for it. Not editors!

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: If they're going to poke fun at me, I'm going to

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Listen. Listen, Longfellow. You've got brains, kid. You'll get along swell if you'll only curb your homicidal instincts - and keep your trap shut. Don't talk to anybody! These newshounds are out gunning for you.

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: But what about this "Cinderella Man"?

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: That's my job. I'll take care of that. I'll keep that stuff out of the papers - if you'll help me. But I can't do anything if you go around talking to people. Will you promise me to be careful from now on?

turns.speaker: LONGFELLOW
turns.text: Yes, I guess I'll have to.

turns.speaker: COBB
turns.text: Thank you.  If you feel the building rock, it'll be me blasting into this editor.
